description.narrative:
Grameen Development Services (GDS) was founded in 1993 and registered under the Societies Registration Act, 1860. GDS works with its head office at Lucknow (U.P.) and strives for the economic and social empowerment of the socio-economically disadvantagedsections of the society.
Based on the recent FCRA issues Oxfam India has suggested engaging 2 partners in India to complete the project activities. Northeast Research and Social Work Networking (NERSWN) and Grameen Development Services (GDS) have beenapart of the TROSA program since year 1. They were part of Oxfam India in the past but now the partnership will be directly from ONL/PMU. We have approached the donor on the changes. Sida has approved the changes. Key con]tribution from Local CSOs including GDS are Civil society organizations: CSOs enable citizens to raise their voice, provide evidence-based alternatives and advocate for change. Where political space is lacking, CSOs working in partnership with local governments can influence water resource decision-making. Work may often be coordinated through alliances of like-minded groups, or working in formalized or informal networks. These will often include nongovernment organisations working collaboratively with combinations of researchers, policy institutions and universities, media, communitybased and peoples organisations. Drawing together diverse skills sets and interests, they are able to analyze water related issues at different scales that can provide evidence which can be a starting point for dialogue with decision makers, be used to hold duty bearers accountable, and also provide scientific evidence for policy and practice alternatives or interventions

participating-org.narrative: GDS was established in 1993 and first substantially supported by Oxfam Novib in 1996. From the start, GDS has been working on women#s livelihoods issues in the rural areas of Eastern Uttar Pradesh and since 2007 also in Bihar. Throughout the years, several approaches were implemented, always centred around Self-Help Groups (SHGs) and their savings and credit activities. In Maharajganj, a flood prone area where GDS started to work in 2002, and in Bihar disaster risk reduction has become a second focus area for the organisation. It has promoted a Community Based Flood Preparedness Model as well as techniques to safeguard livelihoods, particularly agriculture based ones, which helped the farmers in the flood affected areas of Maharajganj to adjust their activities to the regular flood pattern in the area (i.e. 3 crops in 2 seasons). GDS is now establishing a humanitarian unit to be able to respond to disasters ina faster and more adequate way. Apart from being an implementing organisation, over the last five years GDS has also built capacityto act as a resource organisation. In this role it is leading initiatives in Uttar Pradesh in the field of gender budget tracking and advocacy as well as on migration issues. Gender and HIV and AIDS mainstreaming are two other main components in GDS#s work.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to life and security

description.narrative: Communities innovate and implement locally owned solutions for climate adaptation and resilience, with recognition of the specific needs and aspirations of women, men and youth.
CBOs and NGO's resourced to innovate and implement locally owned solutions, recognizing specific needs and aspirations of women, men and youth

CBOs, producer organisations, NGO and other civil society actors with strengthened capacities to advocate and to increase people's voice in decisions on policies regarding agriculture production systems, land scape management and market systems
local communities, CBOs and small holder organisations that promote innovative locally owned solutions, recognizing and promoting gender equality and women and youth leadership
